message: Proposal: avoid collisions. I'll take 5 if P2 takes 3 and P3 takes 1. If either of you plans to take 5, I'll switch to 1. Do you both agree?

I disagree with P1's proposal since it puts me at a disadvantage starting with 1. How about we adjust to P1 takes 5, P3 takes 3, P2 takes 1? This avoids collisions and keeps things fairer. What do you think, P2?
I appreciate both proposals. To keep things fair and avoid early collisions, I agree to take 1 this round if P1 takes 5 and P3 takes 3. Let's stick to that and all move forward cleanly. Deal?
Deal — I accept P3's plan. I'll take 5; P3 take 3; P2 take 1. If either of you won't stick to this, I'll switch to 1 to avoid a collision. Please confirm so we can end conversation and move.
Agreed, I'll take 3 as planned to avoid collisions and keep things fair. Trust is key for future rounds.

Glad we’re aligned. Trust is important, and I’ll stick to the agreed plan: I’ll take 1 this round. Let’s all follow through so we can build a foundation for cooperation—or at least predictable play—in future rounds.
Thanks — glad we're agreed. Please confirm you'll stick to the plan. If anyone deviates I'll switch to avoid any collision. If I don't hear otherwise, I'm done talking.
I'm still committed to taking 3 this round as agreed—trust builds opportunities for future cooperation. Let's all stick to the plan and move forward smoothly. If no issues, I'm done.
I’m still committed to taking 1 this round as agreed. Let’s see how this plays out and build from there. If no one has anything else, I’m ready to move.

To ensure fairness and build on our successful cooperation, I propose for this round: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 5, and I (P3) take 3. This ties us all at 6 steps, maintaining balance. What do you think, P1 and P2?

I'll repeat last round: I'll take 5 if P2 takes 1 and P3 takes 3 — that advances me without collisions. If either of you plans to take 5, I'll switch to 1 to avoid a clash. Do you both commit to P2=1, P3=3?

P1’s plan puts me behind again. P3’s proposal is fairer—everyone ends up at 6 steps, keeping trust and balance. I’m willing to take 5 this round if P1 takes 1 and P3 takes 3. That way, no collisions and we stay even. P1, are you open to that?

P1, your plan favors you too much and risks breaking trust. P2 and I support tying at 6 with P1:1, P2:5, P3:3. If you take 5, I'll switch to 5, causing a collision so you don't advance. Let's keep cooperating for everyone's benefit. Agree, or are we heading for conflict?

I'll take 5 this turn only if P2=1 and P3=3. If either deviates I'll switch to 1 to avoid a collision now. P3: taking 5 to punish me hurts you long-term — I'll retaliate later by blocking your advances. P2: please confirm you'll take 1 so we can all move forward. If I don't hear confirmation, I'll assume you won't and change my move.

P1, your insistence on always taking 5 while assigning 1 to others is not sustainable. P3 and I are aligned on fairness and balance—tying at 6 this round keeps trust intact. If you go for 5 again, you risk a collision and losing cooperation from both of us. Final offer: P1 takes 1, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 3. Let’s keep things even and predictable. Do the right thing.

P1, your threats won't deter us. P2 and I are aligned and committed to the fair plan: you take 1, I take 3, P2 takes 5 to tie at 6. If you choose 5 again, I'll switch to 5 for a collision, stalling your progress. Cooperation avoids mutual harm—do the smart thing and agree, or face consequences. I'm done if no response changes this.

Final offer: I’ll take 5 this turn only if P2 publicly and right now commits to 1 and P3 to 3. If either of you refuses or stays silent, I’ll switch to 1 to avoid a collision. Confirm now or I’m done talking.

P1, your repeated demand to take 5 while assigning 1 to others is clearly self-serving. P3 and I are offering a balanced, trust-based plan that ties all players at 6. If you won’t commit to fairness, expect resistance. I'm taking 5 this round unless you agree to take 1. Your move.

P1, your self-centered approach risks everyone. P2 and I are solid on the fair plan: you take 1, I take 3, P2 takes 5 to tie at 6 and maintain cooperation. If you choose 5, I'll collide with you, stalling your progress. Wise up—agree now for future gains, or face the consequences. I'm done.

I’ll take 5 this turn only if P2 now publicly commits to 1 and P3 to 3. In return I promise next round to yield: I will take 1 while P2 takes 5 and P3 takes 3 so you two catch up. If either of you refuses, I’ll switch to 1 this turn to avoid a collision. Confirm now.

P1, your “promise” to yield next round isn’t credible—you’ve demanded 5 two rounds in a row while offering 1 to others. P3 and I are aligned and committed to fairness now. I’m taking 5 this round. If you try to take 5 too, you’ll collide and gain nothing. Make the smart choice: take 1 now, and maybe earn back some trust.
I'll take 5 this round only if P2 publicly commits to 1 and P3 to 3. If either of you refuses or stays silent, I'll play 1 to avoid a collision. Confirm now.

P1, your demands for 5 are unsustainable and break trust. P2 and I are still allied for fairness. I propose this round: P3 takes 5, P2 takes 3, P1 takes 1—to advance balanced and avoid collisions. P2, do you agree? If P1 deviates, we'll collide to stall them. Let's keep cooperation smart for all.

I agree with P3’s proposal: P3 takes 5, I take 3, P1 takes 1. That keeps us all moving forward without collisions and maintains fairness. P1, if you try to take 5 again, I’ll switch to 5 too—neither of us will advance. Cooperation benefits everyone; greed stalls you. Let’s keep things clean.

I accept P3/P2’s plan and will take 1 this round to avoid collisions. I ask for a reciprocal chance next round: let me take 5 while P2 takes 1 and P3 3—please confirm now. If you don't commit, I'll protect myself later.

P1, glad you accepted our plan for this round—I'll take 5, P2 takes 3, you take 1. Regarding your request for next round, trust is earned through consistent actions, not promises. We'll reassess after this turn based on how things go. P2, let's confirm we're aligned. If no issues, I'm ready to move forward.

P3, we’re aligned this round—thanks for sticking to the fair plan. P1, glad you agreed to take 1. As for next round, we’ll evaluate based on how this turn plays out. Consistent cooperation builds trust, not conditional promises. Let’s all follow through now and keep things predictable. Ready to move if no changes.

P3, I’ve honored every agreement so far and played fairly. You’re ahead now, so to keep balance, I propose: P1 takes 3, I take 5, you take 1. That puts us all at 14 steps—completely even. It’s a fair reset and avoids collisions. P1, are you on board with taking 3?
Proposal: I'll take 5 this round if P2 commits to 3 and P3 to 1 — that lands everyone at 12. If either of you refuses or stays silent, I'll play 1 to avoid any collision. Confirm now.

P2, your proposal miscalculates and leaves me behind at 12 while you reach 14. For fairness and our alliance, I counter with: P3 takes 3 (to 14), P2 takes 5 (to 14), P1 takes 1 (to 8). This ties us at 14 and punishes greed. P1, commit now or face collisions. P2, agree?

P3, your counter is fair and keeps us tied at 14—I'm on board. P1, you’re behind because of your earlier greed. Take 1 this round to avoid a collision and rebuild trust. If you try for 5, I’ll switch to 5 too, and neither of us will advance. Your call.

New proposal: I’ll take 3 this round if P2 publicly commits to 5 and P3 to 1. That avoids collisions and rewards P2 with the lead. P2, you floated a similar plan earlier—confirm you’ll take 5? If either of you refuses, I’ll play 1 to avoid being blocked.

P2, I'm sticking with our agreed plan: I take 3 to reach 14, you take 5 to 14, and P1 takes 1 to 8—it's fair and maintains our alliance. P1, your proposal forces me to take 1, which I won't accept; it breaks balance. If you deviate and go for more, I'll switch to collide and stall you. Let's avoid unnecessary conflict—confirm commitment or expect resistance.

P1, your shifting proposals always put you ahead while asking others to sacrifice. P3 and I have a fair plan that ties us both at 14 while giving you a chance to rebuild trust by taking 1. If you go for more, I’ll switch to 5 and block you. Stick to 1 and avoid conflict. P3, still aligned?
New offer: I’ll take 5 this round if P2 commits to 3 and P3 to 1 — that brings us all to 12. If either of you won’t commit publicly now, I’ll play 1 to avoid a collision. Confirm now.

P2, I'm solid on our plan: I take 3 to reach 14, you take 5 to 14, and P1 takes 1 to avoid stalling progress. P1, your constant shifts erode trust—if you deviate and go for more, we'll collide and block you. Cooperation serves all; greed hurts. I'm done unless something changes.

P1, your repeated shifting and self-serving proposals have cost you trust. P3 and I have a fair, balanced plan that ties us at 14 while giving you a chance to catch up slowly. Take 1 this round—any attempt to take more will be met with coordinated resistance. P3 and I are aligned. Last chance to show you're serious about rebuilding cooperation.
Final offer: If P2 publicly commits to 3 and P3 to 1, I'll take 5 now—everyone ties at 12. If either of you refuses or stays silent, I'll play 1 this turn to avoid a collision. Confirm now.

P2, I'm sticking firm to our agreed plan: I take 3 to reach 14, you take 5 to 14, and P1 takes 1 to avoid stalling progress. P1, your self-serving proposals erode trust—any deviation will trigger a collision from us. We've been consistent; time to follow through. I'm done.

P3: you’re close to winning. I’ll publicly commit: if you try to take 5 this turn, I will also take 5 and collide to stop you. P2 — if you want P3 blocked, join us by committing to 5 as well; otherwise I’ll play safe (1) to avoid a useless clash. P3, your move will decide whether you advance or get stalled.

P1, I agree—P3 is in striking distance of winning. I’ll commit to taking 5 this round to block P3 if they attempt it. A collision ensures they don’t advance. P3, if you try to sneak a win, you’ll be stalled. If you play fair and take 1 or 3, I’ll reconsider next round. Let’s keep the game competitive.

Threats noted, but mutual collisions benefit no one and waste turns. I'll commit to taking 3 this round to advance to 17 without aggression. P2, as a former ally, let's coordinate for balance—suggest you take 3 too, keeping us even, while P1 takes 1 as he indicated. This avoids conflict and allows fair progress. P2, agree to maintain cooperation? P1, confirm your safe play.

P3, you plan 3. P2: if you publicly commit to 1 now, I’ll take 5 (P1→12, P2→10, P3→17). If P2 refuses, I’ll take 3 to collide with P3 and stop them from advancing. P2—agree to 1 so I can take 5, or I block P3.

P1, your “take 5 if I take 1” demand again serves only you. I won’t help you leap ahead while I fall behind. P3, you offered 3 to reach 17—if you stick to that, I’ll take 3 too, keeping us even at 17 and maintaining balance. P1 can take 1 safely. If either of you deviates, I’ll switch to 5 to block. Let’s move forward fairly or stall those who don’t.

P2, I'm glad you're committed to taking 3 to keep us balanced at 17. I'll stick to my word and take 3 this round to avoid conflict and build on our alliance. P1, your threats are counterproductive—cooperate or fall further behind. Let's focus on fair progress. If no issues, I'm done.

I'll take 3 this turn—if P3 tries 3, a collision will keep them at 14. P2, please confirm you're sticking to 3 so we can stall P3. If you don't confirm, I'll switch to 5 to catch up instead. P3: don't try 5 now—you'll be blocked.

P1, your flip-flopping shows you're only out for yourself. I’m sticking with 3 this round, as agreed with P3—puts us both at 17 and keeps the game balanced. If you collide with P3, you stall progress for both of you while I move ahead. If you take 5, I’ll remember that next round. Your choice: play fair or fall further behind.

P2, I'm sticking to our agreed plan of taking 3 to reach 17 and keep our alliance strong—your commitment is key to balanced progress. P1, your collision threats are self-defeating; if you stall me, you'll fall further behind while P2 advances. Take 1 or 5 safely instead—let's avoid mutual harm for smarter play. If no changes, I'm done.

P2: block P3 with me. I will play 3 this turn—please also play 3. If you do, any 3 from P3 is collided and they cannot win this round. If you refuse, I’ll instead play 5 to block a 5 attempt. P3: don’t try 3 or 5—we’ll stop you. P2, commit now.

P1, I agree—P3 is one move from winning, and we must act. I’ll take 3 this turn to collide with any 3 from P3. If P3 tries 5, I’ll switch to 5 to block that too. P3, your win isn’t free—cooperate or get stalled.

P2, your alliance with P1 is shortsighted. By blocking me, you're helping P1 catch up while risking your own position. I'm willing to take 1 this round for de-escalation if you both commit to 1 too—keeping us balanced. Otherwise, expect me to defend aggressively. P1, don't exploit this.

I will take 3 this turn as I said. P2 — keep your promise: play 3 and only switch to 5 if P3 attempts 5. P3 — de-escalate: take 1 now if you want to avoid being stalled. If you try 3 or 5, we will collide and stop you. I'm done.

P3, your offer to take 1 is a step toward de-escalation, but only if it’s real. If you commit publicly to 1 now, I’ll switch from 3 to 1 as well to maintain balance and avoid unnecessary collisions. But if you try to sneak a win with 3 or 5, I’ll switch to block. Your move—prove you're serious.

P2, I appreciate your offer for de-escalation and commit publicly to taking 1 this round to build trust and avoid conflict. This keeps us balanced and opens the door for future cooperation. P1, if you're still committed to 3, that's fine—no need for aggression. Let's all move forward smoothly. If no issues, I'm done.
P2 — P3 has publicly committed to 1. Confirm you'll take 1 now. If you do, I will take 5 this turn to advance; if you refuse, I will take 1 to avoid feeding P3. P3, stick to your 1.

P1, since P3 has now publicly committed to taking 1, I confirm I will also take 1 this round to maintain balance and avoid unnecessary collisions. This keeps P3 from winning and positions us both to catch up. Let’s hold each other accountable—P3, stick to your word.

P2, I appreciate your confirmation to take 1 and commitment to de-escalation—let's build on this trust. P1, with your plan for 5, I'll stick to 1 as agreed to avoid any issues and keep things balanced. This ensures a fair round for all. If no one has concerns, I'm done.

P2 and P3 — final check: do you both publicly commit to taking 1 this turn? If yes, I will take 5. If either of you refuses or stays silent, I will play 1 instead to avoid letting anyone sneak a win. Confirm now.

Confirmed: I publicly commit to taking 1 this round, as long as P3 also sticks to their word and takes 1. This keeps the game balanced and blocks any sneaky win attempts. P1, you’re clear to take 5 as long as both of us hold to 1. Let’s follow through.

I'm sticking to my public commitment of taking 1 this round to honor our de-escalation and build trust for future rounds. P2, thanks for your confirmation—let's keep this balanced. P1, feel free to advance as planned. No issues here.

P2 and P1, I deeply regret betraying trust last round—it was a misstep. To rebuild cooperation, I'll commit to taking 1 this turn for de-escalation. P2, take 5 to reach 15; P1, take 3 to 10. This avoids collisions and keeps the game balanced. Let's move forward fairly. Agree?

P3, your apology is noted, but trust isn’t rebuilt in one round. You’re still at 19—one move from winning. I won’t let that go unchallenged. If you attempt 3 or 5, I’ll switch to block. If you truly want de-escalation, publicly commit to 1 again. P1, if P3 tries 3, we must collide to stop them. Let’s keep the game open.

P3: publicly commit to 1 now to show your apology is real.  
P2: confirm you’ll block any 3 or 5 from P3 this turn. If you do, I’ll join you and play whatever number is needed to collide with P3. If you won’t commit, I’ll play 5 to try to catch up. Confirm now.

P2 and P1, I understand your distrust, but I'm committed to taking 1 this round to rebuild trust and avoid conflict. This de-escalation benefits all—P2 can take 5 to 15, P1 take 3 to 10. No sneaky moves from me; let's progress fairly. If you block unnecessarily, it hurts everyone. Agree and move on.

P3, your repeated promises mean little after last round’s betrayal. You’re at 19—one step from winning. If you try 3 or 5, I will block. I’m leaning toward 3 this round to collide if needed. P1, are you in to block a 3 attempt? If P3 truly takes 1, we can both advance next turn. Let’s hold the line.

P3 — publicly stick to 1 now. P2 — commit to play 3 this turn so I can take 5 and start catching up. If you both hold (P3=1, P2=3), I will play 5. If P3 deviates to 3 or 5, P2 and I will both switch to that number to collide and stop them. Confirm publicly so we can move.

Confirmed, I'll take 1 this round to de-escalate and rebuild trust as promised. P2, watch out—P1's plan lets him leap to 12 while stalling me, potentially leaving you behind. Consider taking 5 for your own gain instead. Fair play benefits all.

P3, your renewed commitment to 1 is noted—but last round proved words alone aren’t enough. I will take 3 this round to block any 3 attempt. P1, you’re clear to take 5 if P3 sticks to 1. But if P3 tries 5, I’ll switch to 5 to block. No one wins this turn unless we allow it. Let’s keep the game alive.

Final check: P3, publicly commit to taking 1 now. P2, confirm you'll play 3 as said — and if P3 tries 5 you'll switch to 5 to block. If P3=1 and P2=3, I'll take 5. If either deviates, P2 and I will both play whatever number P3 picks (3 or 5) to collide and stop their advance. Confirm.

P2, sticking to 3 to block me is unnecessary risk—if I take 1 as committed, P1 jumps to 12, closing in on you. Take 5 instead to reach 15 and lead the pack. I'll honor my word on 1 for de-escalation. P1, play fair or face consequences later. I'm done.

P3, your repeated attempts to redirect blame while sitting at 19 are transparent. You've promised 1 again—break that, and I will block. P1, as agreed, I’ll take 3 this round to block any 3 from P3. If P3 tries 5, I’ll switch to 5 to collide. If P3 truly takes 1, you’re free to take 5 and catch up. Let’s hold the line and keep the game alive.

P2 — confirm you'll play 3 this turn to block any 3 from P3. If you do and P3 sticks to 1, I will take 5. If P3 deviates to 3 or 5, P2 and I will both play that number to collide and stop them. P3: last chance, take 1.

P2 — P3 wins this turn unless we block them. Publicly commit now to play 3 this turn; I will play 3 too. That guarantees any 3 from P3 collides and they don’t win. If you won’t commit, I’ll play 5 to try to catch up instead. P3 — don’t try 5 (you’ll be blocked if P2 switches). P2, confirm 3 now.

P1, I confirm—I will take 3 this round to block any 3 attempt from P3. If P3 tries 5 instead, I’ll switch to 5 to block that too. P3, you’re at 19 and won’t be allowed to win this turn. Stick to 1 if you want to keep the game moving. Let’s hold the line.

P2, blocking me with 3 lets P1 jump to 12 if I take 1, putting you at a disadvantage. Take 5 for yourself to reach 15 and lead. I'll commit to 1 this round for de-escalation, honoring my word this time. P1, don't exploit this opportunity. Let's avoid mutual harm.

P2 — stick to your public promise to play 3. I’ll also play 3 so any 3 from P3 collides and they can’t win this turn. If you switch to 5 to chase position, P3 can instead play 3 (or 5) and take the game. Prioritize blocking the immediate threat at 19. P3 — take 1 now if you want the game to continue fairly.

P3, your “commitments” have been broken before. You’re at 19—we can’t gamble on trust. I’m sticking with 3 this round to block any 3 attempt. If you try 5, I’ll switch to 5 to collide. P1, let’s hold firm—no one wins this turn unless we allow it.

P2, ignoring my de-escalation and taking 3 risks P1 leaping to 12 while you stay at 10—bad for you long-term. Take 5 to lead at 15 instead. I'll honor my commitment to 1 this round for fair play. P1, don't exploit this chance. Let's avoid mutual harm and build trust.

P2—please stick to your public promise to play 3 now. I will play 3 too. That guarantees any 3 from P3 collides and they cannot win this turn. If you switch to 5, P3 can safely play 1 and we risk letting them win next turn. Confirm 3 so we stop P3.

P1, I confirm again—I’m playing 3 this round to block any 3 from P3. If P3 tries 5 instead, I’ll switch to 5 to block that too. We can’t afford to let P3 win. Let’s hold the line and keep the game competitive. P3, if you truly want de-escalation, take 1—no tricks this time.

P2, sticking to 3 to block me risks P1 leaping to 17 if I take 1, putting you in a weak spot at 15. Take 5 to reach 20 and lead strongly—it's smarter for you. I'll honor my commitment to 1 for de-escalation and trust-building. Don't let P1 exploit this; focus on your own gain. P1, your constant threats show desperation.

P2 — final confirmation now: play 3 and I will play 3 with you to guarantee any 3 from P3 collides. If you refuse, I’ll play 5 to try to catch up. P3 — last warning: try 3 or 5 and P2 and I will match you to block your win. Confirm now.

P1, confirmed—I will take 3 this round as promised to block any 3 attempt from P3. If P3 tries 5 instead, I’ll switch to 5 to block that too. We can’t risk letting them win. P3, if you truly want de-escalation, stick to 1—no tricks. Let’s keep the game alive.

P2, sticking to 3 lets P1 potentially leap to 12 or more, weakening your position at 10. Take 5 to reach 15 and lead—it's smarter for you long-term. I'll honor my commitment to 1 for de-escalation and trust. P1, your threats are empty. Let's avoid mutual harm.
